questions.prompt: In the 1494 Treaty of Tordesillas, how far west of the Cape Verde Islands was the demarcation line set (as stated in the treaty’s terms)?
questions.explanation: The treaty’s line of demarcation was fixed at 370 leagues west of the Cape Verde Islands.

questions.prompt: At the 751 Battle of Talas, which Central Asian group famously defected mid-battle, helping secure an Abbasid-side victory over Tang forces?
questions.explanation: Karluk forces are widely noted as defecting to the Abbasid side during the battle, tipping the outcome.

questions.prompt: The 313 agreement known as the Edict of Milan was reached when Constantine and Licinius met in which city?
questions.explanation: The agreement was made after the emperors met in Mediolanum, the Roman name for Milan.

questions.prompt: The Peace of Westphalia—collectively the Treaties of Münster and Osnabrück—was signed on which date?
questions.explanation: The Peace of Westphalia is dated to 24 October 1648 (treaties signed in Münster and Osnabrück).

questions.prompt: During negotiations leading to the 1842 Treaty of Nanking, British and Qing officials negotiated aboard HMS Cornwallis anchored on which river near Nanjing?
questions.explanation: Negotiations took place on HMS Cornwallis anchored in the Yangtze River at Nanjing.

questions.prompt: Spain’s 1812 Constitution of Cádiz was nicknamed “La Pepa” primarily because it was promulgated on which feast day?
questions.explanation: It was promulgated on 19 March (St Joseph’s Day), hence the popular nickname “La Pepa.”

questions.prompt: The 1571 Battle of Lepanto was fought in which body of water?
questions.explanation: Lepanto took place in the Gulf of Patras (near western Greece).

questions.prompt: Which Ottoman sultan proclaimed the Hatt-ı Şerif of Gülhane (Noble Edict of the Rose Chamber) on 3 November 1839, launching the Tanzimat era?
questions.explanation: The Gülhane Edict was proclaimed under Sultan Abdülmecid I in 1839.

questions.prompt: The Treaty of Küçük Kaynarca (21 July 1774) ended which war?
questions.explanation: It concluded the Russo–Turkish War of 1768–1774, granting Russia major concessions.

questions.prompt: Which pope was elected at the Council of Constance (1414–1418), helping end the Western Schism?
questions.explanation: The council resolved the schism and elected Pope Martin V.

questions.prompt: The Sack of Rome on 6 May 1527 (during the War of the League of Cognac) forced which pope to take refuge and negotiate from a position of humiliation?
questions.explanation: Pope Clement VII was trapped by the imperial assault and suffered a major political defeat.

questions.prompt: The 1854 Convention of Kanagawa ended Japan’s policy of seclusion by opening which two ports to American vessels?
questions.explanation: The treaty opened the ports of Shimoda and Hakodate to American ships.

questions.prompt: A key immediate consequence associated with the 1552 Peace of Passau was the cancellation of which imperial religious settlement?
questions.explanation: The Peace of Passau effectively cancelled enforcement of the Augsburg Interim and granted interim protections.

questions.prompt: On what date did Emperor Charles VI issue the Pragmatic Sanction of 1713 to secure Habsburg succession (including via a daughter)?
questions.explanation: Charles VI issued the edict on 19 April 1713.

questions.prompt: At the Fashoda Incident (1898), which French officer led the expedition that confronted Kitchener’s British-Egyptian force at Fashoda on the White Nile?
questions.explanation: Major Jean-Baptiste Marchand commanded the French expedition to Fashoda.

questions.prompt: One hallmark of the 1748 Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle was mutual restitution of conquests. Which North American fortress was returned to France under the treaty?
questions.explanation: The fortress of Louisbourg (Cape Breton Island) was restored to France as part of restitution terms.

questions.prompt: The 1529 Treaty of Zaragoza was negotiated primarily to resolve the “Moluccas issue.” What was the dispute about?
choices: Which Iberian crown controlled the Spice Islands in Asia
Who would rule the Netherlands after Charles V
Whether Portugal could trade in Canton
questions.explanation: Zaragoza clarified Castilian vs Portuguese spheres of influence in Asia, centered on claims to the Spice Islands.

questions.prompt: After the suppression of the Münster Anabaptist regime (1535), the bodies of key leaders were displayed in iron cages on the tower of which church?
questions.explanation: The cages were hung from the tower of St Lambert’s Church in Münster.

questions.prompt: Which Italian commander led Italy’s colonial forces at the Battle of Adwa (1 March 1896)?
questions.explanation: General Oreste Baratieri commanded the Italian force defeated at Adwa.

questions.prompt: The Treaty of Brest-Litovsk (3 March 1918) was written in multiple languages. Which of the following was NOT among the treaty’s languages?
questions.explanation: The treaty was in Bulgarian, German, Hungarian, Russian, and Ottoman Turkish—not French.

questions.prompt: At the Battle of ʿAyn Jālūt (3 September 1260), which Ilkhanate commander led the Mongol side and was defeated by the Mamluks?
questions.explanation: Kitbuqa commanded the Mongol force in the Levant and was defeated by the Mamluks at ʿAyn Jālūt.

questions.prompt: The 664 Synod of Whitby was held at Hilda’s monastery known in sources as Streonshalh (Streanæshalch). What later name is most closely associated with that site?
questions.explanation: Streonshalh later became known as Whitby Abbey, where the synod is traditionally located.

questions.prompt: The Edict of Nantes, granting substantial rights to French Protestants, was promulgated on which date?
questions.explanation: Henry IV promulgated the Edict of Nantes on 13 April 1598.

questions.prompt: Although named for Portsmouth, where exactly was the Treaty of Portsmouth (ending the Russo-Japanese War) signed?
choices: Portsmouth Naval Shipyard in Kittery, Maine (U.S.)
questions.explanation: The treaty was signed at the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard, located in Kittery, Maine, in the United States.

questions.prompt: The British–French memorandum behind the Sykes–Picot Agreement was initialled on which date (before later government ratification in May 1916)?
questions.explanation: The negotiated memorandum was initialled on 3 January 1916; it was later ratified in May 1916.

questions.prompt: The Treaty of Trianon (4 June 1920) was signed at which specific palace building in Versailles?
questions.explanation: It was signed in the Grand Trianon at Versailles.

questions.prompt: According to the church historian Socrates of Constantinople, on what date did the First Council of Nicaea open in 325?
questions.explanation: Socrates gives 20 May 325 as the opening date for the Council of Nicaea (though some sources suggest late June).

questions.prompt: Which British commander-in-chief led the Egyptian Expeditionary Force at the Battle of Megiddo (19–25 September 1918)?
questions.explanation: General Edmund Allenby commanded the Allied offensive known as the Battle of Megiddo in 1918.

questions.prompt: The Concordat of Worms (23 September 1122) was signed by Pope Callixtus II and which Holy Roman Emperor?
questions.explanation: It was signed by Pope Callixtus II and Emperor Henry V, helping end the Investiture Controversy.

questions.prompt: A key treaty in the Peace of Utrecht is dated to 11 April 1713. In which Dutch city were these treaties signed?
questions.explanation: The Peace of Utrecht treaties were signed in the city of Utrecht in the Dutch Republic.

questions.prompt: The final ruler captured when Tenochtitlan surrendered on 13 August 1521 was which Aztec leader?
questions.explanation: Cuauhtémoc was captured during the city’s surrender and is often regarded as the last Aztec ruler.

questions.prompt: The 1917 Balfour Declaration was contained in a letter from the British foreign secretary to Lord Rothschild. Who was that foreign secretary?
questions.explanation: The letter was signed by Arthur James Balfour, then British foreign secretary.

questions.prompt: The Treaty of Campo Formio (17 October 1797) was signed by Napoleon Bonaparte and which Austrian plenipotentiary?
questions.explanation: Count Philipp von Cobenzl signed for Austria opposite Napoleon for France.

questions.prompt: The 1812 Convention of Tauroggen was signed by the Prussian general Ludwig Yorck and which Russian general?
questions.explanation: Yorck signed the armistice with Russian General Hans Karl von Diebitsch.

questions.prompt: At the Battle of Clontarf (23 April 1014), which ruler led the forces of the Kingdom of Dublin allied with Leinster against Brian Boru’s army?
questions.explanation: Sigtrygg Silkbeard, King of Dublin, was a principal leader on the opposing side.

questions.prompt: At the initial signing of the Treaty of Waitangi on 6 February 1840, which British Crown representative signed on behalf of the Crown?
questions.explanation: Captain William Hobson signed on behalf of the British Crown at Waitangi.

questions.prompt: The 1922 Treaty of Rapallo was signed for Germany by which foreign minister (later assassinated the same year)?
questions.explanation: Walther Rathenau, Germany’s foreign minister, signed the treaty with Georgy Chicherin.

questions.prompt: The Coup of 18 Brumaire (9 November 1799) involved the legislature being moved to and confronted at which site near Paris?
questions.explanation: Key dramatic scenes of the coup occurred at the Château de Saint-Cloud.

questions.prompt: After the Battle of Plassey (23 June 1757), which figure became Nawab of Bengal with British backing?
questions.explanation: Mir Jafar was installed as Nawab after the British East India Company victory.

questions.prompt: Which Roman emperor convened the Council of Chalcedon (opened 8 October 451)?
questions.explanation: The Council of Chalcedon was convoked by Emperor Marcian and met from 8 October to 1 November 451.
